Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Some say they weren’t given sufficient warning about the power shutoffs and aren’t sure where to go.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago
many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The city states on its website that it is working to identify ‘hotels and other accommodations that can offer discounted rates for residents.’
Document Sources.Source Justification: The city states on its website

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The land movement has created a dangerous situation, and Edison is deciding to disconnect to keep that community safe,” said Jim Hanggi, a spokesperson for the utility. “It is a fluid situation and we’re working on solutions to keep the power flowing but as conditions change we’ll need to adjust to keep the community safe.”

Gordon Leon told LAist he plans to move into a tiny home on his property and bought four generators to power it. He said he’s had no gas for weeks now, but water is still running. The power in his house has been shut off indefinitely, so his plan is to move off the grid.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Impacted residents, many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Leon said he and his neighbors are just trying to 'figure out how to survive.'”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Impacted residents, many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Leon doesn't want to leave his neighborhood because he loves its beauty and that he gets to look at the ocean every day, he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Impacted residents, many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The city’s mayor, John Cruikshank, told LAist on Monday that Southern California Edison should have done more earlier to transition residents off grid and prevent additional outages.

“We’re hearing that our residents want to stay in their homes, and we're doing everything we can to keep them in their homes,” Cruikshank said. “We're going to do everything we can to push the governor and the federal government to provide them funds.”

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: A spokesperson for Southern California Edison on Monday said the power outages will impact some homes longer than others: They say 20 will be without power indefinitely and 38 will be without power for one to three weeks. The rest were slated to be without power for 24 hours.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: A spokesperson for Southern California Edison

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: On Thursday, SoCalGas announced that it was shutting off gas service to additional 29 homes in the western Seaview area and another 25 homes in the Portuguese Bend Beach Club starting at 3 p.m. Friday. The shut-offs are expected to last indefinitely, the utility added.
A spokesperson for Southern California Edison told LAist that the utility is not providing generators because they feel the ground is too unstable for that to be a long-term solution.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: A spokesperson for Southern California Edison

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - Never touch a fallen power line. Call the power company to report fallen power lines.
- Do not drive through standing water if downed powerlines are in the water.

- If you’re in a vehicle with a fallen power line on it, stay in the vehicle and remain calm until help arrives. It is OK to use your cellphone to call 911. If you must leave the vehicle, remember to exit away from downed power lines and exit by jumping from the vehicle and landing with both feet together. You must not touch the vehicle and the ground at the same time. Then proceed away from the vehicle by shuffling and not picking up your feet until you are several yards away.
- Water and electricity don’t mix. Water is an excellent conductor of electricity. Do not step in or enter any water that a downed power line may be touching.
- Look first. Don't touch. The person may still be in contact with the electrical source. Touching the person may pass the current through you.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - Call or have someone else call 911 or emergency medical help.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - Turn off the source of electricity if possible. If not, move the source away from you and the affected person using a nonconducting object made of cardboard, plastic or wood.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - Once the person is free of the source of electricity, check the person's breathing and pulse. If either has stopped or seems dangerously slow or shallow, begin cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) immediately.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - If the person is faint or pale or shows other signs of shock, lay him or her down with the head slightly lower than the trunk of the body and the legs elevated.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: - Don't touch burns, break blisters, or remove burned clothing. Electrical shock may cause burns inside the body, so be sure the person is taken to a doctor.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted
